Reviews.Title: Superb quality pix, Like the AA batteries, one big drawback.
Reviews.Author: Christopher J. Olsen
Reviews.Content: I'm giving this camera four stars, but one star is for the low price.  First of all, the people who give it low marks for picture quality need to either read the manual or understand a few things about photography.  The picture quality is actually excellent if you know what you are doing.  The wide angle lens allows you to take very good pictures in rather low light WITHOUT a flash.  With a 25mm equivalent lens, you can actually get by with a shutter speed of 15th of a second and have your picture come out.  That means if you set the ISO to 400, you can shoot in some pretty low light.  Conversely, the 21x zoom is the equivalent to more than 500mm in 35mm.  If you are zoomed in that much, you either need to be on a tripod or have a shutter speed of 1000th of a second or less.All in all, if you know what you are doing with this camera, the picture quality is superb.Battery?  There are many of us who prefer cameras that run on AA batteries for the versatility.  That's all I'm going to say about that.And finally, the one big drawback.  There is no way to control the aperture and shutter speed.  I've found a few workarounds for this, but if I want to be able to shoot a shot at 1/1000th of a second or five seconds, regardless of exposure, I'd like that option.

Reviews.Title: You'll like this camera if this is the sort of camera you are looking for
Reviews.Author: UnseenWorld
Reviews.Content: About me: I'm a pro photographer and I wanted a knocking around camera that met several requirements. First, I wanted a camera that was relatively small. Second, I wanted one that's relatively lightweight. Third, I wanted one that was very "point and shoot." Fourth, I wanted quite a bit of zoom range, not 5x or even 10x, but much more. Fifth, I wanted a camera capable of taking very good photos. Finally, I wanted one that was cheap.My work camera is a Nikon D600. This is technically more of a high-end "prosumer" camera than a true pro camera. That said, it gets the job done for me and the extra money spent on a true pro camera wouldn't provide any benefit to a guy who shoots pretty girls mostly indoors. If I shot sports or wanted a camera to take with me to the summit of Mt. Everest, I might spend two or three times as much, but the D600 has all the image quality of its much more expensive siblings and weighs less, which has become important to me. Even with the D600, I can have sore shoulders after 6 or 8 hours of continual shooting.While my D600 could be put into Program or Auto mode and be used as a point-and-shoot and still take great photos, and while I had a wide-range (28-300mm) zoom, it didn't meet the other three requirements of being small, light in weight, and inexpensive.My need was for a camera I could take with me all day without its weight wearing me out, without keeping me distracted as I manage all of its controls, and for a camera that wouldn't have me in tears if I dropped it or it was stolen. Let's face it: walking around with a D600 and a big lens is an invitation to have it taken at gunpoint!I had been keeping my eyes open for just the right camera at a great price when I got an offer from one of the major discounters (not Amazon, sorry to say) offering the Nikon L310, factory refurbished, for just $99.99. I checked out the specs and the reviews and decided that this looked like a good bet. At just about $100, it would still be worth it even if was a bit disappointing.I've had it for a little while now and I'm pretty pleased with it. Were I not a pro, I'd probably be totally happy with it, but I'll try to look at it from the point of view of the casual photographer who mainly takes personal, family, and vacation photos. Looked at that way, it's a great buy even at twice $99.99.Getting back to my requirements and how it satisfies them...Size: The L310 is quite small. Photos of it without something to give one a sense of scale tend to be a little misleading, since it looks kind of like a DSLR, but in truth it's about 60%-75% of a Nikon or Canon DSLR in physical dimensions.Weight: The L310 weighs about a third what my D600 with its 28-300mm lens mounted weighs, much of that weight coming from the four AA batteries that power it. It's not so light that a strong breeze could blow it off a picnic table, though hurrican force winds might.Ease of Use: For a pro, it's frustratingly easy. There is no (M)anual mode whatsoever. No (S)hutter Priority or (A)perture Priority modes, either. Every photo you take with it is either totally or mostly totally automatic. You can control ISO but most of your control actually comes down to choosing what program mode to use. And it has a lot of different program modes. Almost too many, I'd say. If anything, they overdid the program modes bit. Mostly, you'll be safe to just leave it in AUTO or EASY AUTO mode.Zoom range: The L310 has a 21x optical zoom. This is fairly high. Other cameras have 24x or more, but 21x is a lot given that many cameras brag of having something like a 5x zoom. Of course, the problem as your zoom factor gets stronger is that the more zoom you use, the more camera wobble can screw up your shots making them soft or even blurred.Quality of photos: It's a Nikon. The optics are good, the camera is well-designed, and so the photos are certainly plenty good for a camera in this range. This camera is about as thoroughly automatic as a camera can be. It's designed by some of the best camera and optics engineers in the world. How could the photos not be good?!!!Price: I've already talked about the price. Like I said, I got a refurbished (=newish) one for near $100. Amazon and others are selling them new at $200 or so and that's still a very good price.Now, I didn't get into resolution as a requirement, and let me tell you why. The L310 is 14.1 megapixel camera, which is more than you need if you are even thinking of a camera in this general range. To tell you the truth, you can get a good 8x10 photo from a 3 megapixel camera. The current trend toward selling 20+ megapixels is insane even in the pro category. Unless one is shooting a mural, 14 megapixels is much more than adequate. In fact, since the camera gives you the option of shooting smaller photos, I'd set the camera to take photos no larger than 2048z1536 (3 megapixels). For family or vacation photos, this is more than large enough. If you take a lot of 14.1 megapixel photos, it will chew up a lot of space on your hard drive, and before you know it you'll be buying external drives just to house all of your needlessly large photos. Also, the larger the photos you take, the sooner they'll fill up your memory card.Anyway, in conclusion, for the everyday non-pro user who wants a camera that meets the primary requirements I listed in the beginning, you won't do a whole lot better for $200.One final tip: If you want an in-depth look at the camera, you can view the user's guide here:[...]

Reviews.Title: I like it!
Reviews.Author: McKenzie, NH
Reviews.Content: I got this Camera from my hubby for Christmas. I am not sure what he paid but it was a black Friday deal. I really like it. I think the key is figuring out the different modes and using them right. The zoom is phenominal. I have taken action shots at my sons basketball games and at first they were burry, but we figured out different settings that work great and it is so nice to get close ups of our kids at a holiday concert etc. It did not come with an SD card but I just took the one I had from my beat up digital camera and was good to go.

Reviews.Title: For old school SLR/film users, this is a great transition camera to start with.
Reviews.Author: David Chambers
Reviews.Content: I fought the digital age from day one.  I am now becoming a fan.  I haven't touched 1/10th of its features and I am very impressed with the image quality.I love the feel of a classic Nikon SLR

Reviews.Title: Love my new camera!!
Reviews.Author: alongmore1
Reviews.Content: I am not a photo taking person but I purchased this camera after doing my research and it is perfect for a beginner like myself. The quality is great I just love it.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding camera
Reviews.Author: D. Phillips "DAVEinTN"
Reviews.Content: I grew up using a Polaroid Instamatic camera, in high school I took a photography class and it changed my photo taking forever. For the longest time I use using fully manual 35MM cameras. But as the digital age took over my 35mm camera went the way of the dinosaur.  Since the majority of my photos now are of grandchildren and our dog....a fully automatic camera made sense.....onto my review.I needed to replace my old Panasonic DMC-F7Z that was showing it's age. I had many too choose from on Black Friday, but the price on this unit and the Nikon name made it a simple choice. We've taken many photos and a video, while it's strength is not the video, it shines in the photo area. I will admit, when we first got it I had a few issues with it, but after doing some reading of the manual (on disc) I figured out what I was doing wrong. The talk you hear about focusing issues is somewhat true, in low light conditions with the zoom it has trouble focusing, but in average to good lighting no issues. For the price, a steal of a deal.  I would buy this camera again.Side by side with the Panasonic, this unit is about the same size, I like a camera with some substance, no little boxes for me, it weighs a little more than the Panasonic, again I like that.

Reviews.Title: Regret my purchase.
Reviews.Author: Just wish it would work
Reviews.Content: Wow, wish I had never wasted my time on this camera. I was so excited to get it and ended up really disappointed. There is *A LOT* of noise in the pictures. Forget using it inside. All my outdoor pictures had more noise and artifacts than my old Canon from 10 years ago. My camera phone has turned into my "go to" camera since this one takes such lousy shots.The most annoying thing is, I have only used this camera a few times and it no longer works. I have had it for a total of 4 months and when I click the shutter button sometimes it works, sometimes the camera shuts down (the batteries are brand new). It is a completely random phenomenon. Also, there are already some pixels out on the display. I have taken excellent care of this camera and it is already unusable.I've been trying for the past 3 hours to send this camera back for repair. Nikon makes it as difficult as possible, my guess is that they hope people will get frustrated and give up. I called in, spoke to rep for about 15 minutes, thought it was scheduled. Nope. I was sent a link to schedule. Link didn't work on three different browsers. Finally got through by finagling my settings and this model number isn't even listed in their returns system, which means scheduling is not possible.I will NEVER purchase Nikon again!

Reviews.Title: OMG GREAT BUY LOVE ITTTTTTTT
Reviews.Author: chemistry4life
Reviews.Content: when i got the package in the mail the first thing i saw was the amazon smile on the box and i was hoping that once i opened it i would be smiling as well. to make a long story short i was very impressed when i opened the box and saw the camrea. the fluid amazing quality pictures that it takes is unbeatable for the price. its no SLR, obviously, but for this price you cant go wrong. it says i bought but the box came in brand new unopened, it seems like amazon has a restriction on selling it new so dont let that turn you off becasue mine came in new. Cheers. will update soon once i take this badboy to the botanical gardens

Reviews.Title: A pretty good camera
Reviews.Author: K P B
Reviews.Content: I use this camera for my job. I chose this camera because it offers 640 X 480 image size plus the zoom length and wide angle (just be aware to steady camera when zooming). I take about 500 photos per day, and my rechargeable AA batteries last about 700 photos. Mostly pleased; I only wish I could find filters (to protect the lens mostly) but it seems to be an odd size.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Camera
Reviews.Author: B. Diane Dupuy
Reviews.Content: This camera was a College Graduation Gift to one of my Granddaughters.  She and her future husband loved it.  They have been enjoying capturing all of their many adventures.

Reviews.Title: My camera came exactly as described (except for the part about being factory sealed)
Reviews.Author: Cameron M. Addison "Camolette"
Reviews.Content: I love the camera so far, I was really excited to get such a nice camera for such a good price. It arrived very quickly as well!

Reviews.Title: I love my new camera
Reviews.Author: Mom in small town
Reviews.Content: it's great love the way pics turn out, it was awesome during the fireworks, we even were able to get fireworks in the background of a pic that was so awesome.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera
Reviews.Author: research
Reviews.Content: Good point and shoot camera but short on instruction manual and features.Older Nikons had far more options. This one is short.

Reviews.Title: Best Compact Camera Ever!! FULL REVIEW
Reviews.Author: Jane Parker
Reviews.Content: For those who are planning to purchase a new compact camera with is packed with amazing features that is ideal for both professionals or even amateurs, the Nikon Coolpix L310 is definitely the best option. If this is the compact camera that you are considering to buy either for professional use or for recreational purposes, it is best to check on the available digital camera review sources that you can easily find online. All you have to do is to check on a reputable Nikon Coolpix L310 review so that you will be provided with a glimpse on what the compact camera is all about. Of course, it can also provide you with an insight whether the features and the overall functioning of the camera can cater to your needs and preferences [...][READ MORE ON NIKONCOOLPIXL310(dot)COM]

Reviews.Title: Blurry Pictures
Reviews.Author: Candee
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for our holiday trip to Disney World. All my pictures that I was in moving such as rides or if the kids were moving came out extremely blurry. I am a very disappointed that there is no shutter control for this. unless you have extremely steady hand forget about getting the shot of a bird flying through the sky, I only gave it two stars because the zoom was exactly what I was looking for. I got a great shots that were in long distance but they were steady. I couldn't even finish taking pictures of the kids opening up their presents because all the pictures were blurry. I do not recommend if you are looking to take pictures in action. My Kodak took better action pictures than this. too bad Kodak phased out their cameras.

Reviews.Title: Why should you buy this camera?
Reviews.Author: Just a guy "Me"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera on a whim - something I could carry with me all the time for quick shots, in place of my more expensive cameras.When I opened it up, I noticed right away the power on button is not protected. So if you should power it on by mistake like in a bag/coat/purse etc - there is a good change you can damage the lens as it telescopes out. A web search found several users that have lens opening issues - but to be fair any camera with a telescoping lens is at risk, but the power button on this camera makes it pretty easy.There is way more image noise in the image than I expected. The lower the light, the more the noise. Image sharpness and overall quality are so so. The long zoom is not very good for sharpness and forget the digital zoom for anything other than curiosity.In all honesty this camera produces SLIGHTLY better images than a cellphone. The zoom makes this a better camera than a cellphone, but not by much.For the money it's ok - it's best for 4x6 prints, a cheap trip camera and web sharing. I am returning mine as I know the lens opening will be an issue.** I just realized that you can turn the camera on with the lens cap on and it does not pop the lens cap off like some cameras do - so if this happens you can jam the lens.

Reviews.Title: Ok outside, HORIBBLE inside
Reviews.Author: mi655321
Reviews.Content: Had the camera for about a month. Pictures outside are pretty good. Inside though (regardless of picture mode) are lousy... either out of focus, blurry, or completely overexposed by the flash (target about 5 feet away).  In order to take an ok picture with the flash I have to cover over half of the flash with my finger. I've tried changing the settings but nothing seems to change the flash power. This camera would be good if you don't plan on taking any pictures inside.  I've found that about one in ten shots inside is ok.  I've yet to see a "good" picture taken inside.

Reviews.Title: Save your money.
Reviews.Author: Evelyn W. Lowman
Reviews.Content: This camera drains batteries like crazy, which wouldn't be so bad except the picture quality is not good.  Some settings, the picture are excellent.  It's been hard to find the right scene options to use.  And the auto function doesn't make any better pictures than trying to choose the settings yourself.  Not worth the money.  My pocket camera that cost 1/3 less is better.

Reviews.Title: Blurry.....  Oh so blurry!
Reviews.Author: Steph
Reviews.Content: We were so excited to get this new camera! Now, we're glad the store took it back and gave a full refund. It was so blurry! I had to set the camera on the countertop to steady it (and I do NOT have a shakey hand), and it was STILL blurry for still shots. I had about 5/50 pics come out decent. We werevery disappointed with our purchase and we're now just glad that we didn't throw our old camera out..... tuens out, compared to the L310, our old Sony CyberShot takes a pretty darn good picture!!

Reviews.Title: So cool!!!
Reviews.Author: Patel
Reviews.Content: [...]This is the actual place I bought it from. Price was around $130. Pretty good deal!This is a Bridge camera. By that I mean in the middle between point and shoot and Dslr. The l319 does not have a eye piece so you have to use the screen for all your shots. Very easy to use and decent picture quality. Great for someone looking for more control, creativity and 720 HD video over a point and shoot. Nice zoom range 25mm - 525mm. The image stabilization is worthless at the far end of the zoom. The l319 is not for the pro but great for someone just starting out or just wants a nice picture without all the fuse of dialing in a bunch of settings. For under [$]you can use it, learn something about photography and if you break it or you decide to upgrade you only have [$] in it.

Reviews.Title: Nice but you get what you pay for
Reviews.Author: M. Becker
Reviews.Content: if you look around you can get this for as low as $99...the big plus is the optical zoomHow are the pictures...not bad...not exceptional...image quality, image stabilization and focus when zoomed seem a little hit and miss...also:  a big practical issue:  no rechargeable batteries included...takes 4 AA...also:  no SD card included...Overall:  it is not bad...if you take into account the price...it is very good...but you are not getting a $250 camera for $99...there are obvious compromises...if you are going to buy an inexpensive camera to use for the next 10 years...you may be better spending an additional $50 or $100...but if you accept what it is...a nice but inespensive camera...it is fine...

Reviews.Title: nikon L310
Reviews.Author: judy
Reviews.Content: Bought it to go to Israel. really like it, The only problem is that where you hold it with your right thumb is very near the buttons to review or change scene, Often I would hit it instead of the grab point, I have not developed the pix yet but I think it is a good product.

ProductInfo.Features:
14.1 Megapixels
21x wide-angle optical Zoom-NIKKOR glass lens
720p HD Movie Recording
102 MB Built-in Memory Storage Capicity
ProductInfo.Name: Nikon Coolpix L310 14.1MP Digital Camera with 21x Optical Zoom - BLACK
